Bailey Whitfield Diffie

Biography

Whitfield Diffie is born in June 5th 1944 in Washington, D.C. He is an American cryptographer, famous for inventing public key cryptography cooperating with Martin Hellman and Ralph Merkle.

Career and Research

Diffie graduated with a local diploma but did not take the statewide Regents examinations that would have gave him an academic diploma. The reason why he didnâ€™t, was because he had already earned an admission to Massachusetts Insistute of Techology due to excellent results in standardized tests. He later got a Bachelor in mathematics in 1965.
On graduation he got a job at MITRE Corporation developing Mathlab (an early symbolic manipulation system) and many more non-military applications. In 1969 he joined the Standfort University Artificial Intelligence lab working with his director, John McCarthy. He worked on LIST and correctness problems in computer rograms while still researching about cryptography.
Diffie left Standfort Institute in 1973 persuing independent researches in cryptography. Through 1975 Diffie worked with Martin Hellman while Ralph Merkle joined in 1976.
The famous Hellman and Whitfield Diffie "New Directions in Cryptography" got published in 1976. The paper introduced a radical new method of distributing cryptographic keys, granting secure transactions, communications or any online interaction granting a different level of privacy and security.
In 1992, Diffie was awarded an honorary docotrate by the Swiss Federal Institute of Technlogy in Zurich, in 2010 the IEEEE Richard W. Hamming Medal with both Ralph Merkle and Martin Hellman.
In 2015 he won the 2015 Turing Award.

Turing Award 2015

In memory of A.M. Turing
